abstract.p: Nobel Prize-winning Portuguese novelist Jose Saramago will discuss is work at Paul Robeson Campus Center at Rutgers University (S)

block.p: What would happen if the Iberian Penisula floated out to sea? If a proofreader inserted the word ''not'' into books? Or if God and the Devil negotiated about evil? These are some of the things that happen in the books of Portuguese novelist Jose Saramago, winner of the 1998 Nobel Prize for Literature.
''Blindness,'' ''Stone Raft'' and ''Baltasar and Blimunda'' are among his best-known novels, many political parables related to the fall of the Salazar government in 1974.

Next Sunday, Mr. Saramago will be coming to Newark, a city with one of the largest Portuguese populations outside of Portugal, to talk about his work. He will speak at the Paul Robeson Campus Center at Rutgers-Newark at 2 p.m.
